customer_addr:
12749 Nine Mile Rd
South Lyon, MI 48178

citations.narrative:
The licensee has eight puppies in sheltered housing using the garage at the front of the facility. The licensee has the day
camp kids play with the puppies for socialization. There are also three Maine coon cats housed inside the garage with the
two females intended for breeding.
All animals held at the facility that are used for exhibition, breeding and/or brokering must be held in compliance with the
Animal Welfare Act regulations and standards to ensure humane treatment of the animals held by the facility.
Each exhibitor shall comply in all respects with the regulations set forth in part 2 and the standards set forth in part 3 of
this subchapter for the humane handling, care, treatment, housing, and transportation of animals.
To be corrected by August 3, 2023

citations.desc: Primary conveyances (motor vehicle, rail, air, and marine).
citations.narrative:
While on inspection a truck with a horse trailer attached entered the facility. The inspection host stated they were
returning from a party. We walked over to inspect the trailer and to ensure compliance with the transportation standards.
There was an unsecured plastic transportation container in the back of the open pickup bed. I asked the employee what
was in the transport container and she stated two rabbits. Other materials transported in the pickup bed were fencing,
manure rakes, water buckets and a black garbage bag.
Rabbits in a carrier that is loose in the back of a truck bed can be injured or killed in the event of an accident or sudden
stop.
The animal cargo space of primary conveyances used in transporting live rabbits shall be designed and constructed to
protect the health, and ensure the safety and comfort of the rabbits contained therein at all times.
To be corrected from this day forward, July 20, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The licensee acquired a ring-tailed lemur on May 22, 2023. The licensee stated the date of birth, listed on the APHIS
Form 7020 under the Remarks column, was March 10, 2023. The licensee does not have a documented enrichment plan
for the ring-tailed lemur or instructions from the attending veterinarian concerning special consideration for infant or young
primates and singly housed primates.
Nonhuman primates that are not cared for in a manner that provides species-specific enrichment or special
considerations can result in self-injurious behaviors, such as hair pulling or self-biting.
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote
the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must be in accordance with the currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides, and as directed by the attending
veterinarian. This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. Certain nonhuman primates must be provided
special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and in
accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Nonhuman primates requiring special attention are the
following: Infants and young juveniles and/or individually housed nonhuman primates that are unable to see and hear
nonhuman primates of their own or compatible species.
To be corrected by July 28, 2023

A primary enclosure housing two sheep has chicken wire wrapped around the bottom of the fence. There is an area of
this chicken wire, approximately 12 inches long, where two ends come together that has pulled apart causing sharp
points.
Primary enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the animals contained in the enclosure.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by July 26, 2023

The primary enclosure housing two potbellied pigs has two pig wallows in it that take up approximately 30% of the
enclosure. The pigs have to walk through the thick mud and water to access their water.
Clean, dry access to water must be provided to prevent health issues related to hydration and ability to cool.
A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. The method of drainage shall comply with
applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating to pollution control or the protection of the environment.
If pig wallows are used they must not interfere with the pig's access to food, water and shelter and must be cleaned
regularly to reduce disease risks.
To be corrected by July 26, 2023

The licensee has 7 red kangaroo, 3 foxes and 1 armadillo in enclosures that do not have a perimeter fence around them.
Wild and/or exotic animal enclosures must be surrounded by a perimeter fence. The perimeter fence protects the animals
from unauthorized people entering the facility and causing harm or death to the animals. The perimeter fence prevents
predators from entering the facility and injuring or killing the animals, and acts as a secondary containment in case the
animals escape from their primary enclosure.
A perimeter fence must be constructed around these enclosures to protect the animals from unauthorized persons
entering the facility and having contact with the animals, predators from entering the facility and to contain the animals if
they escape the primary enclosure. A perimeter fence variance can also be requested.
To be corrected by January 1, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensees relative and the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.100(a) 
   
Compliance with standards. 
The licensee has eight puppies in sheltered housing using the garage at the front of the facility. The licensee has the day

this subchapter for the humane handling, care, treatment, housing, and transportation of animals.

3.62(a)

To be corrected from this day forward, July 20, 2023

Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The licensee acquired a ring-tailed lemur on May 22, 2023. The licensee stated the date of birth, listed on the APHIS

3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A primary enclosure housing two sheep has chicken wire wrapped around the bottom of the fence. There is an area of 
this chicken wire, approximately 12 inches long, where two ends come together that has pulled apart causing sharp 
points. 
Primary enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the animals contained in the enclosure.

3.127(c)

The primary enclosure housing two potbellied pigs has two pig wallows in it that take up approximately 30% of the

3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The licensee has 7 red kangaroo, 3 foxes and 1 armadillo in enclosures that do not have a perimeter fence around them.
